results.title: Anzac
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Historical photographs and early newsreels tell the story of the Gallipoli assault; embarkation and transport of 75,000 men in 200 ships from Egypt to Gallipoli; initial landing below cliffs; building a jetty and digging in; main British attack at Cape Helles and subsequent assaults on the heights; hardships, casualties and final evacuation. Commentary by Moray Powell and Peter Carver.

results.title: Payback
results.creator_credit: Penny McDonald, Warwick Thornton and Blackfella Films
results.brief_description: Paddy, an old aboriginal man, has been in jail for twenty years. It is the day of his release. Paddy knows of two laws - white law and black law. The twenty years he has spent doing time for the white man’s law has been in preparation for this one - his payback day.

results.title: Carried away
results.creator_credit: Vonnie von Helmolt, Michael Scott and Destiny Deacon
results.brief_description: A combination of animation and live-action which celebrates the creative process. A stylised exercise using black and white photographs to represent reality and coloured overlays representing flights of fantasy. The artist learns by trial and error to take possession of his creative energy. Useful in the areas of art, media studies and as a stimulus to discussion in English classes.

results.title: Fire of the land (A) [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: This beautifully written, produced and directed documentary by AFTRS student Valerie Bichard encapsulates the emotions and determination of a group of Aboriginal Australians seeking peace and justice in their campaign for Sovereign Rights. Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

results.title: Beneath Clouds
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon, AFFC, Australian Film Commission, New South Wales Film and Television Office, SBS Independent and Autumn Films
results.brief_description: Ivan Sen’s debut feature continues the story of one of his acclaimed short films, ‘Tears’. Two disaffected teenagers, Vaughn and Lena (played by non-professional actors Damian Pitt and Dannielle Hall), meet on the road as they flee their troubled backgrounds and head to the city.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivan Sen, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon, AFFC, Australian Film Commission, New South Wales Film and Television Office, SBS Independent and Autumn Films
results.description:
Ivan Sen’s debut feature continues the story of one of his acclaimed short films, ‘Tears’. Two disaffected teenagers, Vaughn and Lena (played by non-professional actors Damian Pitt and Dannielle Hall), meet on the road as they flee their troubled backgrounds and head to the city. Lena, a light-skinned Aboriginal who passes as white, is looking for the Irish father she only knows from photographs. Vaughn is on the run from a prison farm, going home to see his dying mother who long ago gave him up. He is angry and prone to violent outbursts, especially against white people. Though uncommunicative and wary of each other, the two develop an uneasy, tentative bond as their journey progresses and they encounter various Indigenous and European Australians. With extremely sparse dialogue and little character development, Sen uses visual language to convey the emotional isolation of the pair who are often framed in long shot against the open vistas of the Northern New South Wales rural landscape (shot around Moree), or in extreme close-ups. The chasm between black and white Australia and a continuing history of brutality against Indigenous Australians are underlying themes that run through the film.

Written by Ivan Sen; photography, Allan Collins; music, Alister Spence and Ivan Sen; editing, Karen Johnson.
